ËΩØ‰ª∂ÊúÄÈöæÁöÑÈÉ®ÂàÜÊòØÊûÑÂª∫Ê≠£Á°ÆÁöÑ‰∏úË•ø ÊàëÁü•ÈÅìÂú®ËøôÁÇπ‰∏äÁÆóÈôàËØçÊª•Ë∞É, ‰ΩÜÊòØ, Â§ßÂ§öÊï∞ËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÂπ∂‰∏çÁõ∏‰ø°ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÊòØ, ‰ªñ‰ª¨ËÆ§‰∏∫ËøôÂú®Ë¥¨‰Ωé‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂ∑•‰Ωú; Êàë‰∏™‰∫∫ËÆ§‰∏∫ËøôÊòØÊó†Á®Ω‰πãË∞àÔºõ Áõ∏Âèç,ËøôÁ™ÅÂá∫‰∫ÜÊàë‰ª¨ÂøÖÈ°ªÂ∑•‰ΩúÁöÑÁéØÂ¢ÉÊú¨Ë∫´Â§çÊùÇÊÄßÂíå‰∏çÂêàÁêÜÊÄß, ËøôÊïÖÂ±Ö‰∫ÜÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÊåëÊàò; ‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆæËÆ°Âá∫‰∏ñÁïå‰∏äÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÊúÄ‰ª§‰∫∫Âç∞Ë±°Ê∑±ÂàªÁöÑ‰∏úË•ø, ÁÑ∂Âêé, Âç¥Êó†‰∫∫ÊÑøÊÑè‰ΩøÁî®; ËøôÁßç‰∫ãÂÑø‰∏ÄÁõ¥Âú®ÂèëÁîü; ËÆæËÆ°ËΩØ‰ª∂‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂÄæÂê¨Ê¥ªÂä®, Êàë‰ª¨ÁªèÂ∏∏‰∏çÂæó‰∏çÊàê‰∏∫Á´ïËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏à, ÈÉ®ÂàÜÈÄöÁÅµÂ∏à, ‰ª•ÂèäÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰∫∫Á±ªÂ≠¶ÂÆ∂; ÊäïËµÑÂú®Ëøô‰∏™ËÆæËÆ°ËøáÁ®ã, Êó†ËÆ∫ÊòØÈÄöËøá‰∏ìÈó®ÁöÑ UX Âõ¢Èòü, ËøòÊòØÈÄöËøáÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑËá™ÊàëÊïôËÇ≤, ÈÉΩÂ∞ÜÂ∏¶Êù•Â∑®Â§ßÁöÑÂõûÊä•; Âõ†‰∏∫, ‰Ω†Â¶Ç‰ΩïËÆ°ÁÆóÊûÑÂª∫ÈîôËØØËΩØ‰ª∂ÁöÑÁúüÊ≠£ÊàêÊú¨? Ëøô‰∏ç‰ªÖ‰ªÖÊòØÊçüÂ§±Â∑•Á®ãÊó∂Èó¥... 3. ÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÂÉèËÆæËÆ°Â∏à‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÊÄùËÄÉ ‰ºüÂ§ßÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏à‰ºöÊÄùËÄÉ‰ªñ‰ª¨‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÁî®Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™å; ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂèØËÉΩ‰∏ç‰ºöÁî®ÂêÑÁßçÊúØËØ≠Êù•ËÄÉËôë, ËÄåÊòØËÄÉËôëÂ∫îËØ•ÊòØÂ§ñÈÉ®API/ÁºñÁ®ãAPI/Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢/ÂçèËÆÆËøòÊòØÂÖ∂ÂÆÉ‰ªª‰ΩïÁïåÈù¢; ‰ºüÂ§ßÁöÑÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏à‰ºöËÄÉËôëË∞ÅÂ∞Ü‰ΩøÁî®, ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË¶Å‰ΩøÁî®,Â¶Ç‰Ωï‰ΩøÁî®, ‰ª•ÂèäËøô‰∫õÂØπÁî®Êà∑Êù•ËØ¥‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÊúÄÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑ; Áâ¢ËÆ∞Áî®Êà∑ÁöÑÈúÄÊ±Ç, Á°ÆËÆ§ÊòØËâØÂ•ΩÁî®Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™åÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉ; 4. ÊúÄÂ•ΩÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÊòØÊ≤°Êúâ‰ª£Á†Å,ÊàñÊòØ‰Ω†‰∏çÂøÖÁª¥Êä§ÁöÑ ÊàëÂè™ÊÉ≥ËØ¥: "Á†ÅÂÜúÂè™ËÉΩÁºñÁ†Å"; ‰Ω†ÈóÆ‰ªª‰ΩïË°å‰∏öÁöÑ‰∫∫Â¶Ç‰ΩïËß£ÂÜ≥ÈóÆÈ¢ò, ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÈÉΩ‰ºöÂú®‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊìÖÈïøÁöÑÈ¢ÜÂüüÁäØÈîôËØØ; Âè´Âè™ÊòØ‰∫∫ÊÄß; Â§ßÂ§öÊï∞ËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÊÄªÊòØ‰ºöÂú®ÁºñÂÜô‰ª£Á†ÅÊó∂Âá∫Èîô, Â∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÂΩìÈùûÊäÄÊúØËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à‰∏çÊòéÊúóÊó∂; ‰Ω†‰∏çÂøÖÁª¥Êä§ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å‰πüÊòØÂ¶ÇÊ≠§; ÂΩìÂæàÂ§öËΩÆÂ≠êÂ∑≤ÁªèÂ≠òÂú®Êó∂, Â∑•Á®ãÂõ¢ÈòüÂæàÂÆπÊòìÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÈáçÊñ∞ÂèëÊòéËΩÆÂ≠ê; ËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÂπ≥Ë°°Ë°å‰∏∫, ÊúâÂæàÂ§öÁêÜÁî±ËÆ©‰Ω†Ëá™Â∑±ÂÜçÊù•‰∏ÄÈÅç, ‰ΩÜÊòØ, Ë¶ÅÊèêÈò≤ËøôÁßç "Ê≤°Âú®Ê≠§Áé∞ÂÆû"(‚ÄúNot Invented Here‚Äù) ÁªºÂêàÁóá; 5. ËΩØ‰ª∂ÊòØËææÂà∞ÁõÆÁöÑÁöÑÊâãÊÆµ ‰ªª‰ΩïËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÁöÑ‰∏ªË¶ÅÂ∑•‰ΩúÊòØ‰∫§‰ªò‰ª∑ÂÄº; ÂæàÂ∞ëÊúâËΩØ‰ª∂ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁêÜËß£Ëøô‰∏ÄÁÇπ, Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÂÜÖÂåñÁöÑÂ∞±Êõ¥Â∞ë‰∫Ü; ÁúüÊ≠£Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÂÜÖÂåñÂêé, ËÉΩÂØºËá¥Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑ‰∏çÂêåÊñπÂºè, ‰ª•ÂèäËßÇÂØüÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁöÑ‰∏çÂêåÊñπÂºè; Â¶ÇÊûúÁúüÁúüÁöÑÁõ∏‰ø°ËΩØ‰ª∂ÊòØ‰ªéÂ±û‰∫éÁªìÊûúÁöÑ, ‰Ω†Â∞±‰ºöÂáÜÂ§áÂ•ΩÊâæÂà∞ÁúüÊ≠£"ÈÄÇÂêàÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑", ÊúâÊó∂ÂèØËÉΩÊ†πÊú¨‰∏çÊòØËΩØ‰ª∂; 6. ÊúâÊó∂‰Ω†ÂøÖÈ°ªÂÅúÊ≠¢Á£®ÈîØ,Áõ¥Êé•ÂºÄÂßãÁ†çÂ±é Êúâ‰∫õ‰∫∫ÂÄæÂêë‰∫éË∑≥ÂÖ•ÈóÆÈ¢ò, Âπ∂Á´ãÂç≥ÂºÄÂßãÁºñÂÜô‰ª£Á†Å; ÂÖ∂ÂÆÉ‰∫∫ÂæÄÂæÄÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁ†îÁ©∂ÂíåÈô∑ÂÖ•Á°¨‰ª∂ÂàÜÊûêËøõËÄåÁò´Áó™; Âú®Ëøô‰∫õÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏≠,‰∏∫Ëá™Â∑±ËÆæÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™Êà™Ê≠¢Êó•Êúü, ÁÑ∂Âêé, ÂºÄÂßãÊé¢Á¥¢Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à; ÂΩì‰Ω†ÂºÄÂßãËß£ÂÜ≥ÈóÆÈ¢òÊó∂,‰Ω†ÂæàÂø´ËÉΩÂ≠¶‰π†Âà∞Êõ¥Â§ö, Ëøô‰πüÂ∞ÜÂºïÂØº‰Ω†Ëø≠‰ª£Âà∞Êõ¥Â•ΩÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à; 7. Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰∏çËÉΩÂæàÂ•ΩÁöÑÁêÜËß£ÊâÄÊúâÂèØËÉΩÊÄß, Â∞±Êó†Ê≥ïËÆæËÆ°Âá∫Â•ΩÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªü ËøôÊòØÊàë‰∏ÄÁõ¥Âú®Âä™ÂäõËß£ÂÜ≥ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò, Âõ†‰∏∫, ÊàëÁöÑËÅåË¥£‰ΩøÊàëÂú®ËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÁöÑÊó•Â∏∏Â∑•‰Ωú‰∏≠Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äËøú; Â≥é‰∏äÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁîüÊÄÅÊòØ‰∏ÄÈ°πÂ∑®Â§ßÁöÑÂ∑•‰Ωú, ‰ΩÜÊòØ,‰∫ÜËß£‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÂèØËÉΩÁöÑËá≥ÂÖ≥ÈáçË¶Å; Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰∏ç‰∫ÜËß£ÁªôÂÆöÁîüÊÄÅ‰∏≠Êúâ‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÂèØËÉΩÁöÑ,‰ª•Âèä‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÂèØÁî®ÁöÑ, ÈÇ£‰πà‰Ω†Â∞ÜÂèëÁé∞Èô§‰∫ÜÊúÄÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò‰πãÂ§ñ, ‰∏çÂèØËÉΩËÆæËÆ°Âá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêàÁêÜÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÊù•Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊâÄÊúâÈóÆÈ¢ò; ÊÄªËÄåË®Ä‰πã, Ë¶ÅË≠¶ÊÉïÈÇ£‰∫õÂæàÈïøÊó∂Èó¥Ê≤°ÊúâÁºñÂÜô‰ªª‰Ωï‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑ‰∏ìÂÆ∂; 8. ÊØè‰∏™ÁöÑ‰∫Ü‰∫ÜÁöÑÈÉΩÂæàÁ≥üÁ≤ï,ÂÖãÊúç‰∏´ÁöÑ Bjarne Stroustrup ÊúâÂè•ÂêçË®Ä: "Âè™Êúâ‰∏§ÁßçËØ≠Ë®Ä: ‰∫∫‰ª¨Êä±ÊÄ®ÁöÑËØ≠Ë®Ä, ÂíåÊ≤°‰∫∫‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑËØ≠Ë®Ä"; Ëøô‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÊãìÂ±ïÂà∞Â§ßÂûãÁ≥ªÁªü; Ê≤°Êúâ"Ê≠£Á°Æ"ÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑ, ‰Ω†Ê∞∏ËøúÊó†Ê≥ïÂÅøËøòÊâÄÊúâÊäÄÊúØÂÄ∫Âä°, ‰Ω†Ê∞∏ËøúÊó†Ê≥ïËÆæËÆ°Âá∫ÂÆåÁæéÁöÑÁïåÈù¢, ‰Ω†ÁöÑÊµãËØïÊÄªÊòØÂ§™ÊÖ¢; Ëøô‰∏çÊòØÊ∞∏‰∏çËÆ©‰∫ãÊÉÖÂèòÂæóÊõ¥Â•ΩÁöÑÂÄüÂè£, ËÄåÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁªô‰Ω†ËßÇÁÇπÁöÑÊñπÂºè; Â∞ëÊãÖÂøÉ‰ºòÈõÖÂíåÂÆåÁæé; Áõ∏Âèç, Âä™ÂäõÊåÅÁª≠ÊîπËøõÂπ∂ÂàõÂª∫‰∏Ä‰∏™‰Ω†ÁöÑÂõ¢ÈòüÂñúÊ¨¢Âú®ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Â∑•‰Ωú, Âπ∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÊåÅÁª≠ÂàõÈÄ†‰ª∑ÂÄºÁöÑÂÆú‰∫∫Á≥ªÁªü; 9. Èù¢ËØïÂØπ‰∫éÂëäËØâÊüê‰∫∫Â∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫Âõ¢ÈòüÊàêÂëòÊúâÂ§öËµû,Âá†‰πéÊØ´Êó†‰ª∑ÂÄº Èù¢ËØïÊúÄÂ•ΩËä±Âú®‰∫ÜËß£Êüê‰∫∫ÊòØË∞Å, ‰ª•Âèä‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂØπÁâπÂÆö‰∏ì‰∏öÈ¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÂÖ¥Ë∂£Á®ãÂ∫¶‰∏ä; ËØïÂõæÊé®Êµã‰ªñ‰ª¨Â∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫Â§ö‰πà‰ºòÁßÄÁöÑÂõ¢ÈòüÊàêÂëòÊòØÂæíÂä≥ÁöÑ; Áõ∏‰ø°Êàë, ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∫∫ÊúâÂ§öËÅ™ÊòéÊàñÊòØÂ§öÂçöÂ≠¶‰πü‰∏çËÉΩÂæàÂ•ΩÁöÑËØÅÊòé‰ªñ‰ª¨Â∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫‰∏ÄÂêç‰ºòÁßÄÁöÑÂõ¢ÈòüÊàêÂëò; Ê≤°Êúâ‰∫∫‰ºöÂú®Èù¢ËØï‰∏≠ÂëäËØâ‰Ω†‰ªñ‰ª¨‰∏çÂèØÈù†/Áà±Ëæ±È™Ç/Ëá™Ë¥üÊàñÊòØ‰ªé‰∏çÂáÜÊó∂ÂèÇÂä†‰ºöËÆÆ; ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÂ£∞Áß∞‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂØπËøô‰∫õ‰∫ãÊÉÖÊúâ"‰ø°Âè∑"... 142.title: Âª∫ËÆÆÊ∏ÖÂçï:

144.body: ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂèÇËÄÉ ÂæàÊúâ‰∫∫‰∏çÂêåÊÑèÊâÄÊúâËßÇÁÇπ: January 25, 2023 at 7:25 pm Hard disagree with most of the 20 items. Writing software is difficult, tedious and needs real work. No silver bullet libraries, no methodology, no framework, no IOT, no amount of unit tests will get the work done faster. Developers collect tools, libraries and pet technologies and make projects go over their time and budget by doing it. Code should encapsulate algorithms and not be structured other wise. Code should follow the business logic and be readable and match business requirements easily. Forgetting history keeps the productivity and industry down. Microsoft re-discovering the same old technology which existed on 1960s mainframes for the 7th time just to sell products, trademark buzzwords, training, certification and everything is an anchor around the modern developer‚Äôs neck. Think file transfer -> X12 -> serial communication -> raw socket packets -> corba -> xml soap -> xml http -> Rest JSON http -> gRpc as a 50 year journey of rediscovering the same thing repeatedly, each not really that much better than the older technologies, wrapping mounds of interlarded crud on top of fragile, hard to program libraries and the square peg in a round hole mismatch. Refusing to hold W3C and large tech companies accountable for not fixing web HTTP, HTML, CSS and JavaScript for 25+ years. ‚Äì How can I create a control which has HTML, CSS, JS which has encapsulated CSS, encapsulated HTML, encapsulated JS without a 10,000 file framework? ‚Äì How to match HTML DOM elements with JS without using quoted magic strings? Quoted magic strings were proven anti-productivity and anti-quality in the 1960s ‚Äì How to have a UI without the everything is a call back and function pointer? Function pointers with modern wrappings are just as bad as the 1060s computed jump to function tables Forgetting that tech is a business with a 7 year hype cycle, with the new thing being embryonically hyped for 2 years by cutting edge bloggers, then 2 years by sales marketing of companies, then 3 years of disappointment for companies trying to implement it. Followed by, abandonment when the ROI does not work out. Resume driven development, just for business persons. And yes, there‚Äôs a new hype every 2 years to waste time and money on Not holding tech companies accountable when they release major products, .net core, which have less than a 5 year full support lifecycle. Long term support .net is under 3 years. That is a forced upgrade every 3 years for every .net system just to pass the IT auditors at a large company Devaluing your own worth and work as a developer by telling everyone that the proposed product/task is easy. Software dev is hard work, less than 1 of a 1000 people can even do it poorly. I would not go to a brain surgeon that told everyone that what he does is easy. Forgetting that software development is a hard, tedious, isolated job where people desiring lots of human interaction will rapidly leave the field by their own choice and lots of people not getting into the field by their own choice. Not telling people that you as a developer have to say ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs too expensive‚Äù or ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs too risky‚Äù as a regular part of your job. Persons not developing software treating you poorly with career ending consequences just because you won‚Äôt accept the death march cross to bear of impossible requirements of an impossibly short deadline Not helping your fellow developers out. Speak well of your co-developers, team, and industry. Don‚Äôt downplay the difficulty, complexity or contribution of software. Not calling people out when they think that more data, metrics for everything will automatically solve problems. Ask for a business case, ask for the questions they want to answer (in written form), get the business case and questions they want to answer from the requestor, make sure they are approved before committing to a tight deadline Not damaging the next developer on your project ‚Äì too many technologies, framework of the month, just another nuget package, one more class, have another 3 patterns, data on disk, data in database structure and consistency is not important and, yes, this system will never receive/send upstream/downstream data Accepting code without parameter checking, error handling or in-line comment documentation ( cough vendor‚Äôs happy path ‚Äòdoc‚Äô page or cough signature only documentation with no example code or error handling.) Misguided acceptance that best practices are best and not just a short nicely sized blog entry. Best practices, in many cases, do not scale for large 1,000,000+ line of code systems and make maintenance harder. Not challenging the ‚Äòmore technology is better‚Äô approach

167.body: ÂéüÊñá: Rust Bug Minimization Patterns - The {pnk}f(eli)x Blog Update 19 November 2019: fixed miscellaneous typos and a bug in the invariance example pointed out by readers both privately and on reddit thread. I also added a section near the beginning to draw attention to techniques that are somewhat Rust-specific and may not be broadly known. Âø´ËØë: Hey there again! I have been pretty busy with Rust compiler tasks, so no there has not been a blog post for a few months. But now, here we are! While I was working some particularly nasty bugs recently, I put a lot of effort into bug minimization: the process of taking a large test case and finding ways to remove code from the test while preserving the test‚Äôs ability to expose the same bug. As I worked, I realized that I was following a somewhat mechanical process. I was using regular patterns for code transformation. At some point, I said ‚Äúyou know, I‚Äôm not sure if everyone is aware of these patterns. I only remember some of them while I am in the middle of a bug minimization session.‚Äù Since the Rust compiler team always wants to help newcomers learn ways they can contribute to the project, I realized this could be the ideal subject for a blog post. And, to try to keep things concrete, I‚Äôm going to try to drive the presentation by showing an actual bug being minimized. (Or rather, I‚Äôm going to recreate the minimization that I already did. So if it seems like I am rather conveniently picking transformations that always seem to work: You‚Äôre right! I‚Äôm cheating and not telling you about all the false paths I went down during my first minimization odyssey on this bug.
167.title: BMP:ÊúÄÂ∞èbugÊ®°Âºè

168.body: Oh, and one other thing: A lot of the ideas here are applicable to many languages, and so its possible readers have already heard about them or discovered them independently. However, a few of the techniques leverage features that are not universal to languages outside of Rust. Specifically: ‚Äúcfgmenting‚Äù makes use of Rust‚Äôs attribute system to remove items in a lightway fashion. ‚Äúloopification‚Äù makes use of the fact that the Rust allows the divergent expression loop { } to be assigned any type. ‚Äúloopification‚Äù via pretty-printer leverages the compiler‚Äôs (unstable) ability to inject loop { } for all function bodies. Bisecting the module tree makes use of Rust‚Äôs support for a mix of inline and out-of-line modules to allow one to quickly swap code in and out. So, without further ado: here is the odyssey of my minimization of rust-lang/rust#65774
168.breadcrumbs: Rust ÊäÄËÉΩ ¬ª BMP:ÊúÄÂ∞èbugÊ®°Âºè ¬ª The Rust specifics
168.title: The Rust specifics

169.body: What does ‚Äúminimal‚Äù mean anyway? The objective of a ‚Äúminimal‚Äù test case could mean minimize lines of code; or the number of characters. It is also good to minimize the number of source files: one file, cut-and-pastable into play.rust-lang.org, is especially desirable. One could even argue that the number of nodes in the abstract syntax tree is a better metric to use than text-oriented metrics when minimizing. Minimizing the source test in this way can yield a good candidate for a regression test to add to the compiler test suite when the bug is (hopefully) eventually fixed. But those syntactic metrics of minimality overlook something: My own end goal when minimizing the code for a bug is a better understanding of the bug: a better understanding for myself, and for other developers who are reading the test case. I am writing this post from the viewpoint of a rustc developer. So I may have a slightly skewed view on what is useful or minimal.And for such understanding, there are other metrics to keep in mind: Minimize the amount of time the compiler runs before it hits the bug. Minimizing the compiler‚Äôs execution time before failure serves two purposes: It makes every future run of this test faster, which can accelerate your pace of minimization. When the rustc developers themselves examine the behavior of the compiler on the test, they will be grateful to have a shorter execution trace of the compiler to analyze. (Such time reduction often occurs anyway when you remove lines of code and/or dependencies; I just want to point out that it has value in its own right.) As a concrete example of how reducing imports may help expose a bug‚Äôs root cause: some people will have a bug that occurs with some combination of #[derive(Debug)] and a call to format! or write, and the test showing the problem may be only a few lines long. But it hides a lot of complexity behind those uses of derive, macros, and std::io trait machinery; a longer test that defines its own trait, a local impl of that trait, and a small function illustrating the same bug, may make the bug more immediately apparent to a rustc developer. Minimize dependencies: reduce the number of language features in use and the number of imports your test uses from other crates (including the std library!). This can help expose the essential cause of the bug, potentially making it immediately apparent what is occurring. Minimize your jumping around in the source code. If you can fit all the code needed to recreate the bug onto your monitor screen at once, by any means necessary, that is a serious accomplishment. Less time spent scrolling through a file or switching editor windows is more time you can spend thinking about the bug itself. To be clear: Often a minimum amount of code needed for understanding does correlate with a minimum amount of code needed for reproduction. (This explains why using lines-of-code or the size of the syntax tree as a metric can be useful when reporting a bug.) The over-arching goal in minification is to remove all distractions: to reduce the problematic input (in this case, Rust source code) to its essence: a minimal amount necessary to understand the problem. Why not build it up from scratch? Its worth pointing out that at some point, maybe even at the outset, you may have a sufficiently rich understanding of the bug that you can go straight to building up a minimal example from scratch. And that‚Äôs great , go for it! However, this post is dedicated to the problem of what you can do when you haven‚Äôt hit that level of understanding. When you‚Äôre looking at a set of files that make up over 90,000 lines of code, you want a set of semi-mechanical techniques to take that test input and strip it down to its essence. To be honest, the most effective methodology is going to use a blend of build-up and tear-down. As you are tearing down the 90,000 lines of code, there should be a voice in the back of your head asking ‚Äúcan we now try what we‚Äôve learned to try to build up a minimal example?‚Äù
169.title: Philosophical meandering
